sen.j: 百万遍知恩寺（ひゃくまんべんちおんじ）は、京都市左京区にある浄土宗大本山の寺院。
sen.e: The Hyakumanben Chion-ji Temple is the Grand Head Temple of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect, which locates in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Hyakumanben Chion-ji Temple, located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is the Grand Head Temple of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect.
Hyakumanben Chion-ji Temple, located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is the Grand Head Temple of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect.

sen.j: 「百万遍」（ひゃくまんべん）の通称で知られる。
sen.e: It is famous for the common name of 'Hyakumanben.'
It is famous by its common name, 'Hyakumanben.'
It is famous by its common name, 'Hyakumanben.'

sen.j: 山号は長徳山。
sen.e: The sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Mt. Shotoku.
The sango (literally, "mountain name," the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Mt. Shotoku.
The sango (literally, "mountain name," the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Mt. Chotoku.

sen.j: 院号は功徳院。
sen.e: The Ingo (name of temple's title) is Kudokuin.
The Ingo (a temple's title name) is Kudokuin.
The ingo, a title given to a Buddhist temple, is Kudokuin.

sen.j: 本尊は阿弥陀如来。
sen.e: The honzon (principal image of Buddha) is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata).
The honzon (principal image of Buddha) is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata).
The honzon (principal image of Buddha) is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata).

sen.j: 京都における浄土宗四ヶ寺本山のひとつであり、法然上人二十五霊跡第22番札所でもある。
sen.e: It is one of the four head temples of the Jodo Sect in Kyoto and the twenty-second fudasho (temples where amulets are collected) of Honen Shonin's 25 Sacred Sites with historic associations.
It's one of the four head temples of the Jodo sect in Kyoto and the twenty-second fudasho (temple in which amulets are collected) of Honen Shonin's 25 Sacred Sites with historic associations.
It's one of the four head temples of the Jodo sect in Kyoto and the twenty-second fudasho (temple in which amulets are collected) of Honen Shonin's 25 Sacred Sites with historic associations.

sen.j: 御詠歌「われはただ仏にいつか葵草 心のつまに掛けぬ日ぞなき」
sen.e: Its goeika (song in praise of the Buddha) is that 'I want to see Buddha some day by always praying for Buddha like a grass of Aoi (hollyhock).'
sen.cmt: 定訳不明ですが、「http://press.jodo.or.jp/newspaper/1991/199103_289_6-7.pdf」を参考に訳しました。
sen.e: Its goeika (song in praise of the Buddha) is, 'I want to see Buddha some day by always praying for Buddha like a stalk of Aoi (hollyhock).'
Its goeika (song in praise of the Buddha) is, 'I want to see Buddha some day by always praying for Buddha like a stalk of Aoi (hollyhock).'

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: もとは皇円阿闍梨の住房比叡山功徳院の里坊で、平安時代前期に円仁が創建したものと伝えられる。
sen.e: It was originally a satobo (small village temples) of the Kudokuin Temple of Mt.Hiei, which was a residence of Koen Ajari, and was said to be founded by Ennin in the early Heian period.
It was originally a satobo (small village temple) of Kudokuin Temple at Mt. Hiei, which was a residence of Koen Ajari, and was said to have been founded by Ennin early in the Heian period.
It was originally a satobo (small village temple) of Kudokuin Temple on Mt. Hiei, which was a residence of Koen Ajari, and was said to have been founded by Ennin early in the Heian period.

sen.j: 賀茂社との関わりが深く、神宮寺として、御所の北、今出川（京都市上京区、現在の相国寺付近）にあった。
sen.e: It had a deep relationship between the Kamo-sha Shrine, and located at Imadegawa (Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, around the present Sokoku-ji Temple), which was the north of gosho (Imperial Palace) as Jingu-ji Temple (temples associated with shrines).

It had a deep association with Kamo-sha Shrine, located at Imadegawa (Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, around the present-day Sokoku-ji Temple), which was the north of gosho (Imperial Palace) as Jingu-ji Temple (a temple associated with a shrine).

It had a deep association with Kamo-sha Shrine, located at Imadegawa (Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, around the present-day Sokoku-ji Temple), which was the north of gosho (Imperial Palace) as Jingu-ji Temple (a temple associated with a shrine).

sen.j: その所在地から、賀茂の河原屋といった。
sen.e: From its location it was called Kamo no Kawaraya.
It was called Kamo no Kawaraya, based on its location.
It was called Kamo no Kawaraya, based on its location.

sen.j: 円仁作とされる釈迦如来像を安置したことから今出川釈迦堂、などとも称された。
sen.e: Since Shakyanyorai-zo (the statue of Shakyanyorai) which was said to be made by Ennin was placed, it was also called Imadegawa Shakado.
Because Shakyanyorai-zo (the statue of Shakyanyorai), which was said to have been made by Ennin, was placed there, it was also called Imadegawa Shakado.
Because the statue of Shakya nyorai, which was said to have been made by Ennin, was placed there, it was also called Imadegawa Shakado.

sen.j: 法然は度々この地を訪れていた。
sen.e: Honen sometimes visited this place.
Honen sometimes visited this place.
Honen sometimes visited this place.

sen.j: 法然が賀茂の河原屋に一時住んだのは、賀茂の神職から招かれたといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that Honen lived this Kamo no Kawaraya temporarily because he was invited by a Shinto priest of the Kamo.
It is said that Honen lived at Kamo no Kawaraya temporarily because he had been invited by a Shinto priest of the Kamo.
It is said that Honen lived at Kamo no Kawaraya temporarily because he had been invited by a Shinto priest of the Kamo.

sen.j: 法然入滅後、弟子の勢観房源智は賀茂の河原屋をついで、功徳院神宮堂とし、法然の御影を安置して、法然を開山第一世とした。
sen.e: After the Honen's nirvana, his disciple Seikanbo Genchi succeeded Kamo no Kawaraya and named it as Kudokuin-Jingudo, where he placed the portrait of Honen and enshrined him as the founder.
After Honen's nirvana, his disciple Seikanbo Genchi succeeded Kamo no Kawaraya and called it Kudokuin-Jingudo, where he placed the portrait of Honen and enshrined him as the founder.
After Honen's nirvana, his disciple Seikanbo Genchi succeeded Kamo no Kawaraya and called it Kudokuin-Jingudo, where he placed the portrait of Honen and enshrined him as the founder.

sen.j: 念仏の道場とし、伽藍を整備し、如空のとき功徳院知恩寺と称した。
sen.e: He made it as dojo (place of Buddhist practice or meditation) of nenbutsu (Buddhist prayer) and built Buddhist temple, and Nyoku named it as the Kudokuin Chion-ji Temple.
He made it a dojo (place of Buddhist practice or meditation) of nenbutsu (Buddhist prayer) and built a Buddhist temple, and Nyoku called it Kudokuin Chion-ji Temple.
He made it a dojo (place of Buddhist practice or meditation) of nenbutsu (Buddhist prayer) and built a Buddhist temple, and Nyoku called it Kudokuin Chion-ji Temple.

sen.j: 1331年（元弘元年）第8世善阿空円のとき、京都に疫病が蔓延し、後醍醐天皇の勅により七日念仏百万遍を行い疫病を治めたことから「百万遍」の号が下賜された。
sen.e: In 1331 at the era of the eighth Zenna Kuen, a plague raged through Kyoto and he performed the ritual of seven days nenbutsu Hyakumanben (literally, "a million times") by an order of the Emperor Godaigo and ended the plague, and consequently, the temple was given the title of 'Hyakumanben.'

In 1331, during the era of the eighth Zenna Kuen, a plague raged through Kyoto and he performed the ritual of the seven-day nenbutsu Hyakumanben (literally, "a million times") by the order of Emperor Godaigo and ended the plague; consequently, the temple was given the title 'Hyakumanben.'

In 1331, during the era of the eighth Zenna Kuen, a plague raged through Kyoto and he performed the ritual of the seven-day nenbutsu Hyakumanben (literally, "a million times") by the order of Emperor Godaigo and ended the plague; consequently, the temple was given the title 'Hyakumanben.'

sen.j: 1382年（弘和2年：永徳2年）相国寺が建立される際に一条小川に移された（京都市上京区一条通り油小路上ルに元百万遍町の町名が残る）。
sen.e: In 1382 when the Sokoku-ji Temple was built, it was moved to Ichijo Ogawa (a town name of Moto Hyakumanben Cho remains at Ichijo-dori, Aburano-koji Agaru, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City).
In 1382, when Sokoku-ji Temple was built, it was moved to Ichijo Ogawa (the town name of Moto Hyakumanben Cho remains at Ichijo-dori, Aburano-koji Agaru, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City).
In 1382, when Sokoku-ji Temple was built, it was moved to Ichijo Ogawa (the town name of Moto Hyakumanben Cho remains at Ichijo-dori, Aburano-koji Agaru, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City).

sen.j: 1592年（文禄元年）には豊臣秀吉の寺地替えにより土御門（寺町通り荒神口上ル）に移された。
sen.e: In 1592 it was moved to Tsuchimikado (Teramachi-dori Kojinguchi Agaru) by an order to change the land of temples of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
In 1592, it was moved to Tsuchimikado (Teramachi-dori Kojinguchi Agaru) as instructed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, in order to change the land of the temples.
In 1592, it was moved to Tsuchimikado (Teramachi-dori Kojinguchi Agaru) as instructed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, in order to change the land of the temples.

sen.j: 江戸時代に入り、1662年（寛文2年）現在の北白川の地に移転した。
sen.e: In the Edo period, it was moved to the present place in Kita Shirakawa.
In the Edo period, it was moved to its present location in Kita Shirakawa.
In the Edo period, it was moved to its present location in Kita Shirakawa in 1662.

sen.j: 現在
sen.e: Recent situation
Recent situation
Recent situation

sen.j: 境内や本堂・庫裡はしばしばフリーマーケットの会場として貸し出されており、特に京都古書研究会主催で開かれる「秋の古本まつり」（会期は概ね10月末から11月初めまで）の会場となっていることで知られている。
sen.e: Its temple precincts, Hondo (main hall) and kuri (priest's kitchen and living room) are often lent as the site of flea market, and especially it is famous for the site of the 'Autumn Secondhand Book Fair' (held usually from the end of October to the beginning of November) held by Kyoto Kosho Kenkyukai (Kyoto Secondhand Book Club).

Its temple precincts, including the hondo (main hall) and kuri (priest's kitchen and living room) are often lent as the site of a flea market, and it's particularly famous as the site of the 'Autumn Secondhand Book Fair' (usually from the end of October to the beginning of November) held by Kyoto Kosho Kenkyukai (Kyoto Secondhand Book Club).

sen.j: 昭和57年（1982年）に、御影の胎内から「法然上人御骨」と墨書きされた紙に包まれた骨が発見された。
sen.e: In 1982 the bone rapped in a paper and written as 'the bone of Honen Shonin' by black ink was discovered from the body of the goei (image of a deity, Buddha, royal, noble, etc.).
